Document.Content:
Methadone, codeine and acute haemorrhagic necrotising pancreatitis: which came first? See comment in PubMed Commons below Acute haemorrhagic necrotising pancreatitis lead to the death at home of a young female who was on a methadone maintenance programme. Toxic levels of codeine with potentially lethal levels of methadone and morphine were found at post-mortem. Whether opiates caused the pancreatitis or were the consequence of self-medication for pain is impossible to differentiate. Forensic toxicology may pose the question but be unable to provide the answer. 23395525; Tormey WP Forensic science international. 2013/2/12

See comment in PubMed Commons belowForensic Sci Int. 2013 Mar 10;226(1-3):e52-3. doi: 10.1016/j.forsciint.2013.01.020. Epub 2013 Feb 8.Methadone, codeine and acute haemorrhagic necrotising pancreatitis: which came first?Tormey WP, Sabah M, Moore TM.AbstractAcute haemorrhagic necrotising pancreatitis lead to the death at home of a young female who was on a methadone maintenance programme. Toxic levels of codeine with potentially lethal levels of methadone and morphine were found at post-mortem. Whether opiates caused the pancreatitis or were the consequence of self-medication for pain is impossible to differentiate. Forensic toxicology may pose the question but be unable to provide the answer.Copyright Â© 2013 Elsevier Ireland Ltd.
